metadata.title: Dysphagia Assessment  Modified Barium Swallow (Adults)
synonyms: swallowing disorder assessment, modified barium swallow (adults)
deglutition disorder assessment, modified barium swallow (adults)
modified barium swallow (adults): swallowing disorder assessment
modified barium swallow (adults): deglutition disorder assessment
barium swallow, modified (adults): swallowing disorder assessment
barium swallow, modified (adults): deglutition disorder assessment
description: A modified barium swallow study (MBSS) is a recorded (either on videotape or digital media) fluoroscopic examination of a patient’s swallowing function performed by a speech-language  pathologist (SLP) in conjunction with a radiologist during which a patient is asked to swallow varying amounts of barium mixtures.(1,2)Barium mixtures for an MBSS are prepared with barium sulfate (BaSO 4), which is chemically inactive while it is in the body.(28) Barium sulfate is used because it provides contrast along the digestive tract allowing for the structures of swallowing to be visualized as it passes through the mouth and pharynx.(28)MBSS is used to identify the presence of an oropharyngeal dysphagia as well as the patient’s risk for aspiration.(1,2) Additionally, the SLP can utilize the MBSS to determine and teach appropriate compensatory strategies and/or therapeutic exercises to a patient with dysphagia(1,2)
The term MBSS is interchangeable with both VFSS and VSE; these descriptions all refer to the same procedure
A barium swallow procedure is a test to examine esophageal anatomy and physiology; the barium swallow is not the same test as an MBSS(3)
indications: An MBSS is indicated in patients with known or suspected dysphagia(27)

MBSS is indicated in certain patients with dysphagia who have been identified based on the outcome of an in-depth  clinical swallow examination (CSE) –An in-depth  CSE should always precede an MBSS so that the SLP can determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for the MBSS(2) –For detailed information on an in-depth  CSE, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: In-depth Bedside Swallow Examination (Adults) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709037

In some cases, a patient will be referred as an outpatient for an MBSS by his or her physician –An MBSS is sometimes included as part of a comprehensive medical workup if a physician is attempting to determine a patient’s underlying diagnosis –An MBSS is warranted in patients with a history of frequent upper respiratory infections, known or suspected aspiration pneumonia, basilar pulmonary fibrosis, ventilator dependency, or as follow up after receiving therapy for dysphagia(27)

Swallowing G-code set.G8996: Swallowing functional limitation, current status at time of initial therapy treatment/episode outset and reporting intervals
Swallowing G-code set.G8997: Swallowing functional limitation, projected goal status, at initial therapy treatment/outset and at discharge from therapy
Swallowing G-code set.G8998: Swallowing functional limitation, discharge status, at discharge from therapy/end of reporting on limitation

CPT codes.code: 92611 motion fluoroscopic evaluation of swallowing function by cine or video recording

reimbursement: Reimbursement for the procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this procedure Indications for Procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Prior to an MBSS, check that the patient is not on NPO status (nothing per oral) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review the patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members if possible to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, ensure that if food and liquid are mixed with the barium for trials in MBSS, they do not contain these allergens(11)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(13)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (i.e., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(1,13)
Stay with the patient during the entirety of the MBSS. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(13)

The patient must be able to stand, sit, or be otherwise positioned upright in the fluoroscopic examination area to prevent as much aspiration of the barium contrast as possible(1) –Following the MBSS, the patient’s head should be elevated to an angle greater than 30° for 20–30  minutes to prevent reflux-related  aspiration(1)
Any clinician performing an MBSS should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR as choking is a hazard and possible complication of an MBSS(13)

If and when aspiration of barium contrast occurs during an MBSS, proceed with caution; patients with significantly compromised respiratory function might not be able to tolerate any aspiration safely(1) –Refer to specific clinic/hospital policies and procedures for how to continue an MBSS once aspiration has occurred(1) –For most patients, small amounts of aspirated barium contrast pose no harm; however, each institution has policies related to the acceptable amount of aspirated barium contrast(1)

indications for procedure: Dysphagia Dysphagia is the term that refers to difficulty swallowing and/or a swallowing disorder(4,5) Complications of dysphagia include malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration and aspiration pneumonia, and death(4,5,7) There are two main categories of dysphagia(5) –Oropharyngeal dysphagia(5,8,9) -Dysphagia involving the oral and/or pharyngeal phase of swallowing -Dysphagia that affects the oral phase only is referred to as oral dysphagia(10) -Dysphagia that affects the pharyngeal phase only is referred to as pharyngeal dysphagia(10) -Dysphagia that affects both oral and pharyngeal phases is referred to as oropharyngeal dysphagia(10) -Oropharyngeal dysphagia is also referred to as high dysphagia (as it involves the higher structures of the digestive tract —the mouth and pharynx) or transfer dysphagia (because it involves the movement of a bolus from the oral cavity through the pharynx and into the esophagus)(28) -Symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia include choking and/or coughing while eating and/or drinking, pocketing food in the cheeks, and loss of food or liquid from the mouth while attempting to swallow(4,8) –Esophageal dysphagia(5,8,9) -Dysphagia resulting from an impairment of the esophagus or lower esophageal sphincter -Patients generally report symptoms such as regurgitation or heartburn(4,8,9)  -There is a high prevalence of esophageal dysphagia and esophageal motility disorders among patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia(6) For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

Risk factors for dysphagia Cervical osteophytes(5) Ear, nose, throat, or maxillofacial surgery(11) Advanced age(7,9,12) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in older adults, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Older Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708995) Head and neck cancer(4,5) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in patients with head and neck cancer, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Patients with Head and Neck Cancer ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709050) Infection(5) –Botulism(5) –Diphtheria(5) –Lyme disease(5) –Syphilis(5) Neurological disease(4,5,11) –Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with ALS, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis [ALS] ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708986) –Brainstem tumor(1,5) –Stroke(1,4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with stroke, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Post-Stroke ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708770) –Dementia(4) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with dementia, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Dementia ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708935) –Dermatomyositis/polymyositis(5) –Multiple sclerosis(4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with multiple sclerosis, seeClinical Review…Dysphagia: Multiple Sclerosis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708991) –Myasthenia gravis(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with myasthenia gravis, seeClinical Review…Dysphagia: Myasthenia Gravis in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709053 and Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myasthenia Gravis in Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709054) Muscular dystrophy(5) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with muscular dystrophy, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Myotonic Dystrophy in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709072 and Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Oculopharyngeal Muscular Dystrophy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709071) Paraneoplastic syndrome (a group of rare disorders that are triggered by an abnormal immune system response to a malignant tumor)(5) Parkinson disease(4,5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with Parkinson disease, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Parkinson Disease ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708934) Post-polio  syndrome(5) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysphagia in post-polio  syndrome, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Post-Polio  Syndrome ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709062) Sarcoidosis (the growth of tiny groups of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body)(5) Traumatic brain injury (TBI)(5,9) (for detailed information on assessment and treatment of TBI, see Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Traumatic Brain Injury in Adult Patients ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709012 and Clinical Review… Dysphagia: Traumatic Brain Injury in Pediatric Patients ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709008) Prior cervical or esophageal surgery(5,11) Prolonged endotracheal intubation(12) Zenker’s diverticulum(5,9)

According to the American College of Radiology Practice Parameter for the Performance of the Modified Barium Swallow, an MBSS should be performed when there is known or suspected dysphagia or in patients with a condition known to be associated with dysphagia(27)

Aspiration:  An MBSS is an instrumental examination of swallowing that can positively identify aspiration(1) Aspiration occurs when food or liquid penetrates below the level of the vocal folds Normally, aspiration of food or liquid would provoke a cough reflex In many patients with dysphagia, the cough response is not elicited; this is known as silent aspiration(1) –An MBSS is very useful for identifying silent aspiration as it is impossible to determine if a patient is silently aspirating with a noninstrumental CSE alone(1)

exam requirements: A physician’s order is required prior to administering an MBSS
Both an SLP and a radiologist must be present during an MBSS(1)
The SLP must be appropriately trained to administer an MBSS
contrast preparation: Any trial given during an MBSS should be comprised completely of barium (in consistencies of thin liquid, nectar-thickliquid, honey-thick  liquid, pudding thickness, and/or pill) or of food and liquid mixed with barium(1)
Only barium or food/liquid mixed with barium will be visible as contrast on the MBSS(1)

Low-viscosity  liquid barium suspensions (thin barium) are usually prepared with a density of 1.0 g/mL(1)–Adding barium to a food or liquid usually does not change the overall viscosity; however, the SLP must pay closeattention to the viscosity of the food and liquid trials once preparation of the trials is complete for accurate diagnosis ofdysphagia(1)

contraindications precautions to examina: Prior to an MBSS, check that the patient is not on NPO status (nothing per oral) awaiting a procedure; check with patient’s nurse prior to start of examination

Review the patient’s chart and speak to the patient’s nurse and family members if possible to rule out food allergies; if a patient has a food allergy, ensure that if food and liquid are mixed with the barium for trials in MBSS, they do not contain these allergens(11)
In addition to food allergies, be aware of any religious or cultural dietary restrictions prior to giving the patient anything to eat(13)

Observe universal precautions with every patient during dysphagia assessments; take note of any additional precautions required for specific patients (i.e., airborne, droplet, or contact precautions)(1,13)
Stay with the patient during the entirety of the MBSS. Do NOT leave the patient alone with food or drink until the patient is determined to be safe for oral feeding(13)

The patient must be able to stand, sit, or be otherwise positioned upright in the fluoroscopic examination area to prevent as much aspiration of the barium contrast as possible(1) –Following the MBSS, the patient’s head should be elevated to an angle greater than 30° for 20–30  minutes to prevent reflux-related  aspiration(1)
Any clinician performing an MBSS should be trained in the Heimlich maneuver as well as CPR as choking is a hazard and possible complication of an MBSS(13)

If and when aspiration of barium contrast occurs during an MBSS, proceed with caution; patients with significantly compromised respiratory function might not be able to tolerate any aspiration safely(1) –Refer to specific clinic/hospital policies and procedures for how to continue an MBSS once aspiration has occurred(1) –For most patients, small amounts of aspirated barium contrast pose no harm; however, each institution has policies related to the acceptable amount of aspirated barium contrast(1)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -The first step of an MBSS is gathering the patient’s medical history and reviewing his or her medical records(11,13,14) -An interview with the patient and/or family members/caregivers may be appropriate to gather a detailed history of the symptoms and presentation of patient’s dysphagia(15) -Does the patient have a diagnosis that places him or her at an elevated risk for dysphagia?(15) -Is the patient NPO? If so, how long has the patient been NPO?(13)

course of treatment.medical management: Note current and previous management of medical diagnosis (e.g., stroke, head and neck cancer); do any of the medical treatments place the patient at an elevated risk for dysphagia? Chemotherapy and radiation often result in xerostomia (dry mouth);(12) xerostomia is frequently associated with dysphagia(9,12) Current or previous ear, nose, throat, maxillofacial, cervical, or esophageal surgery/procedures might place the patient at elevated risk(5,11)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Review patient’s medical record to determine if a CSE or any instrumental evaluation of the swallow was completed during a previous hospital stay or outpatient visit(13)
Review results of neuroimaging with MRI or CT scan
Review patient’s recent chest X-rays;  be aware of increasing infiltrates in the lungs
Bedbound patients who have aspirated food or liquids during swallowing may present with heterogeneous opacities
on chest Xrays;  the material generally is aspirated into the posterior segments of the upper lobes of the lung or into the superior and posterior basal segments of the lower lobes of the lungs(16)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help Occasionally patients and family members develop their own strategies for managing dysphagia (such as using gravies with all meats or chopping up food into very small pieces) Patients with prior history of dysphagia might already be using an altered diet prior to admission(17) Ask the patient and/or caregiver what types of food and beverages the patient prefers and/or avoids at home(17)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech therapy, occupational therapy, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)(13) -specific foods? -with specific meals? -only halfway through the meal? -when he or she is distracted or having a meal with a group of people?(7)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -For patients who complain of difficulty swallowing, what exactly is the problem with swallowing? -Does food stick in the throat?(9) -Does the patient cough and/or choke while eating or drinking? -Is there pain associated with swallowing?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -When did the symptoms of dysphagia first appear?(18) -How frequently does the patient experience the symptoms of dysphagia?
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with a compromised respiratory status are at higher risk of complications of dysphagia(13,17) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Nasal cannula?(11) -Does the patient have a tracheostomy tube?(11) -When the patient has an uncapped tracheostomy tube, subglottic pressure is reduced and the strength of the swallow is altered(13) -If appropriate, complete Passy-Muir  tracheostomy and ventilator swallowing and speaking valve (PMV) evaluation prior to the MBSS. (For detailed information on assessment and treatment with the PMV , see Clinical T708919) -If the patient has a PMV , food and liquid trials should be presented with and without the valve in place during the MBSS in order for the SLP to determine the benefit of the PMV -Does the patient require ventilator support? -Patients who require ventilator support are at an elevated risk for aspiration during swallowing(13) -Patients who have been orally intubated should be extubated 2448  hours prior to completion of an MBSS to allow for the reduction of laryngeal edema and improved vocal fold function(24,25) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __  -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of oropharyngeal dysphagia?(13)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing, such as reflux or oral/throat pain

relevant tests and measures.general: •Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Patients with extremely large girth might not fit into the fluoroscopy chair; refer to radiology department for height, weight, and girth measurement limitations
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Cardiorespiratory function and endurance:  Refer to specific clinic/hospital protocol regarding cardiorespiratory function requirements for participation in an MBSS -A patient requiring ventilator support might be appropriate for an MBSS if he or she is able to be transported with a portable ventilator(19) -ICU and telemetry patients (i.e., medically unstable patients) should be accompanied by a nurse(2)

Motor function (motor control/tone/learning):  Patients must have adequate muscle tone and control to stand, sit, or be strapped into a fluoroscopic examination chair; additionally, patients must be able to hold their heads in an upright position to accept boluses; refer to radiology department for specific requirements

Oral mechanism exam and related tests:  An extensive oral mechanism examination should be completed prior to or as part of every MBSS.(15) The oral mechanism exam should include: -Buccal/facial muscles: Abnormalities of the buccal and facial muscles may indicate damage to cranial nerve (CN) VII(11) -Is the face symmetrical at rest? -Is the face symmetrical while making movements (smiling, raising the eyebrows, closing the eyes)? -Are there any abnormal movements (twitching, spasms, grimacing)? -Is the patient able to manage his or her secretions?(6,13) -Is the patient’s facial sensation intact?(11) -The patient needs to have adequate sensation of the facial muscles to feel and retrieve any residue during a meal -Is the patient drooling or mouth breathing?(6,11)  -Does the patient present with slurred speech/dysarthria?(11,17) -If the patient presents with dysarthria, he or she might be appropriate for a full speech/language evaluation following completion of the MBSS -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic -Lips:  Abnormalities of the labial muscles might indicate damage to CN VII(11,15) -Are the lips symmetrical at rest? -Are the lips symmetrical during movements? -Is the ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to completely seal his or her lips during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly(14) -Is the strength normal? -Is the lip tissue healthy? -Is there any scarring or cleft? -Is the patient’s labial sensation intact?(11) -If a patient has reduced sensation of either or both lips, the patient is at risk for anterior loss or pocketing of the food on the side of reduced sensation -Tongue:  Abnormalities of the tongue might indicate damage to CN XII(11,15) -Is the tongue normal in appearance? -Any atrophy? -Any tremors present? -Any discolorations? -Any bleeding? -Patients with dry mouth (xerostomia) as a result of chemotherapy, radiation, or other medication side effects may present with dry, cracked tongue tissue or a white/yellow coating on the tongue -Is the ROM normal? -If the patient is unable to reach his or her tongue to the hard palate during swallowing, he or she might not be able to generate adequate pressure to propel boluses posteriorly -Is the strength normal? -If the patient presents with one-sided  weakness of tongue (or lips), he or she is more likely to have food become lodged or pocketed in the oral cavity on the weaker side -Following food and liquid trials, examine weaker side of the oral cavity for residue -Mandible:  Abnormalities of mandibular function might indicate damage to CN V(11) -Is the patient able to maintain jaw closure at rest? -Is ROM normal? -Adequate mandibular ROM is necessary for the patient to adequately masticate solid foods -Is strength normal? -Is the mandible structurally intact? -Patients with head and neck cancer (especially base of tongue cancers) might have had reconstructive surgeries, altering anatomy of the jaw -Hard palate  (15) -Is the hard palate intact? -Any signs of fistulas, fissures, scarring? -Are the height and width normal? -Any prostheses present? -Is the coloration normal? -Soft palate (velum):  Abnormalities of the soft palate (velum) might indicate damage to CN IX(11,15) -Is the coloration normal (should be pink and white)? -Any signs of cleft or bifid uvula? -Does the palate elevate sufficiently and equally? -Use a flashlight to see to the back of the patient’s throat during sustained phonation of the syllable /a/ and repeated phonation of /a-a-a/(11)  -Does the patient sound hyper-  or hyponasal during conversational speech? -Place a small mirror under the patient’s nose during production of nonnasal sounds; if fogging or clouding occurs, this is associated with nasal emission, which would indicate a referral to the otolaryngologist -Teeth  (14,15) -Are there any missing teeth? -Are the teeth in good repair? -Does the patient wear partial or full dentures? -If the patient is edentulous, inquire if the patient has dentures at home; if family is able to bring dentures in, re-examine  mastication with dentures present -Patients who are edentulous might still be able to eat a regular diet; each patient is different -Is there a significant over-  or underbite? function

-For detailed information on compensatory strategies, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy Compensatory ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709081 -Initially, the SLP should attempt different consistencies to determine if this eliminates aspiration (i.e., if the patient aspirates thin liquids, attempt nectar-thick  liquids)(19) -Strategies that can be attempted during this time include: -Alternating solids and liquids(19) -Chin down(19) -Appropriate for patients with delay of pharyngeal swallow, reduced tongue base retraction, reduced laryngeal closure, or reduced laryngeal elevation(19) -Chin up(19) -Appropriate for patients with tongue dysfunction including poor anterior-posterior propulsion of bolus(19) -Downward pressure with the spoon on the body of the tongue to assist initiation of the oral swallow response -Dry swallows(19) -Having the patient swallow multiple times to clear as much residue as possible -Effortful swallow(19) -A maneuver intended to improve tongue base retraction and reduce residue buildup in the valleculae -Head turn to right or left (rotate head towards the damaged side)(19) -Appropriate for patients with unilateral pharyngeal wall weakness, unilateral reduced laryngeal closure, or unilateral vocal fold paresis(19)  -Attempt head turn to both sides to increase pharyngeal pressure in patients with cricopharyngeal dysfunction or reduced anterior movement of the larynx(19) -Liquids given by spoon only -Lying down position (on patient’s back or side)(19) -Appropriate for patients with reduced laryngeal elevation or bilateral pharyngeal wall weakness -Mendelsohn maneuver(19) -A technique that aims to improve laryngeal elevation and cricopharyngeal opening -Supraglottic swallow maneuver(19) -The goal of this maneuver is to close the vocal folds before and during the swallow to prevent aspiration -Super-supraglottic  swallow maneuver(19) -The goal of this maneuver is to close the entrance to the airway (laryngeal vestibule) before and during the swallow to prevent aspiration
-For detailed information on swallow maneuvers, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Swallowing Therapy  Swallow

Maneuvers  an Overview ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709042 and the series of Clinical Reviews on each specific maneuver -The Modified Barium Swallow Impairment Profile (MBSImP): the MBSImP is avalidated, reliable tool developed by Bonnie Martin-Harris  and her team of researchers as a way to standardize modified barium swallow studies.(29,30)The MBSImP allows clinicians to describe a patient’s swallow as visualized on an MBSS in terms of 17 physiological and bolus flow impairments.(29,30)In a validity study of the MBSImP, researchers found that the Oral and Pharyngeal MBSImP scores were associated with Penetration-Aspiration  (PA) Scale scores(29)The MBSImP scores differ from the PA Scale scores in that the MBSImP scores are intended to describe the underlying impairments rather than simply identify the presence of aspiration and/or penetration(29)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: –Special tests specific to diagnosis -Fluoroscopic oral/pharyngeal examination -The fluoroscopic tube should be aimed toward the patient’s oral cavity and pharynx. The radiologist is responsible for properly orienting and operating the fluoroscopic tube throughout the examination. Lateral views and/or anterior-posterior  views may be obtained -In the lateral (side) view, the oral structures (lips, tongue, teeth), the lower rim of the mandible, hyoid bone, epiglottis, laryngeal vestibule, aryepiglottic folds, vallecula, and base of tongue are visible(20) -This view generally comprises the bulk of the examination, as the SLP is able to visualize all of the necessary anatomy and physiology of the swallow -During the examination, the SLP may ask the patient to face the fluoroscopic tube for an anterior-posterior fluoroscopic view(20) -In the anterior-posterior  view, the oral cavity, tongue, and larynx as well as both the right and left pyriform sinuses and trachea are visible; this view is utilized to determine swallowing symmetry(20) -Prior to giving the patient trials of food and liquid, examine swallowing anatomy at rest(1,20) -Are there missing teeth? -Is the anatomy of the lips, tongue, tongue base, pharyngeal walls, velum, nasopharynx, pharyngeal walls, larynx, pyriform sinuses, trachea, or esophagus altered in any way? -Patients with a history of head and neck cancer who have been treated with chemotherapy, radiation, surgery, or a combination of these treatments may have significantly altered swallowing anatomy and physiology(1) -Are cervical osteophytes present along the visible vertebrae? (Large osteophytes can interfere with patient’s ability to clear the pharynx during swallowing)(20) -Are there surgical changes to any aspects of the patient’s anatomy? -When the patient is in the anterior-posterior view, instruct the patient to breathe normally and phonate(1) -Do the vocal folds/arytenoids move symmetrically? -Trials of barium, food, and liquid -The majority of an MBSS is the administration of barium, food, and liquid trials -Any trial given during an MBSS should be comprised completely of barium (in consistencies of thin liquid, nectar-thick  liquid, honey-thick liquid, pudding thickness, and/or pill) or of food and liquid mixed with barium -Only barium or food/liquid mixed with barium will be visible as contrast on the MBSS -Barium, food, and liquid trials can be given via spoon, cup sips, straws, or syringe as needed(3) -Refer to specific clinic/hospital protocol for specifics regarding barium, food, and liquid trials -Begin with small volumes for initial trials (3–5 mL) and progress to larger volumes (10–20 mL)(21) -Swallowing physiology changes with bolus size and consistency.(32)Many different trials should be administered during an MBSS to most clearly define a patient’s dysphagia(21) -Terminating an MBSS too early might not give the SLP an accurate picture of a patient’s ability to swallow(21) -In a study conducted in the United States comparing the results of MBSS examinations administered to 42 acute stroke patients and 25 healthy age-matched  peers, using a single measure or liquid volume to define a patient’s swallowing ability did not distinguish between healthy patients and stroke patients(21)  -When the researchers used a variety of measurements and liquid volumes to identify dysphagia, more clearly defined swallowing disorders became apparent(21) -Encourage outpatients/caregivers to bring foods that are particularly problematic; these foods can be mixed with barium once the patient arrives for the MBSS(3) -Over the course of the MBSS, patients can become fatigued, resulting in reduced efficiency of swallowing. Be cognizant of the patient’s level of fatigue, alertness, and awareness as the MBSS progresses -Liquids -Thin barium/thin liquid mixed with barium(3,13) -Nectar-thick  barium/nectar-thick  liquid mixed with barium(3,13) -Honey-thick  barium/honey-thick  liquids mixed with barium(3,13) -Solids -Pudding-thick  barium/puree mixed with barium(3,13) -Soft-solids  mixed with or coated in barium(13) (soft fruit, cooked vegetables, soft bread, pasta) -Hard solids coated in barium(3,13) (crackers/cookies) -During barium food and liquid trials, the SLP observes both the patient and the fluoroscopy to evaluate swallowing function(1) -Does the patient have difficulty taking the bolus from the spoon or cup?(11) -If the patient loses significant amounts of barium, food, or liquid from the mouth while attempting to eat or drink, adaptive cups and/or utensils might be necessary(13) -Is the patient able to keep the bolus in his or her mouth?(11) -Does the patient effectively swallow his or her saliva?(3) -Following the initial barium, food, or liquid trials, a thin coating of barium will remain and mix with saliva; the SLP can then ask the patient to swallow his or her saliva and observe for aspiration(3) -Is mastication of the solid foods adequate and efficient?(11,13) -If the patient is using more energy to chew the food than he or she is getting from the food itself, solid foods might not be appropriate -Does the patient continue to chew/manipulate bolus until the swallow is complete, or does he or she stop too early, leaving the bolus in the oral cavity? -If the patient does not persist with bolus formation and anterior-posterior  propulsion of the bolus, he or she might not be appropriate for oral nutrition -When a bolus is left in the oral cavity during the meal, the patient is at risk of aspirating this bolus at a later point -If a significant portion of the bolus is left in the patient’s oral cavity, note the area of the oral cavity in which the bolus is left -Does the patient trigger and complete the pharyngeal swallow in a timely manner?(14,22) -Pharyngeal transit time is generally less than 1 second in normal swallowing; significantly increased pharyngeal transit time might indicate pharyngeal wall weakness or reduced pharyngeal pressures(22) -Patients with very impaired swallow function might not be able to initiate a pharyngeal swallow at all(13) -Does the patient require multiple swallows per bolus?(13) -Multiple swallows generated when a patient is attempting to clear residue from the valleculae, pharyngeal walls, and/or pyriform sinuses may indicate weakness of the tongue base, pharyngeal walls, and/or cricopharyngeal muscle, respectively -Keep the fluoroscopic tube aimed at the oral cavity and pharynx throughout the examination; after each swallow, the radiologist should turn the fluoroscopy back on to observe for presence of residue in the oral and pharyngeal cavities(3) -If there is residue, is the patient able to clear the residue independently?(3) Patients who require multiple verbal or visual cues and/or a liquid wash to clear residue are at an increased risk of aspiration -Does the barium, food, or liquid enter the patient’s nasal cavity?(22)  -This occurs due to poorly coordinated or reduced velopharyngeal closure(22) -Does the barium, food, or liquid enter the patient’s laryngeal vestibule? -This is referred to as laryngeal penetration(22) -Does the patient independently clear the penetrated material? -If the patient does not independently clear the penetrated material, is he or she able to clear the penetrated material given a cue?(22) -Does the patient present with aspiration?(1,13,22) -How much of the bolus is aspirated (what percentage)? -Does the patient cough the aspirated material out of the trachea? -Is the aspiration “silent”? -If the patient silently aspirates, is he or she able to clear the aspirated material given a cue to cough or clear his or her throat? -Zenker’s diverticulum(22) -Zenker’s diverticulum is a pocket formed as a result of a herniated pharyngeal or esophageal muscle at the level of the cricopharyngeal muscle(22) -Zenker’s diverticulum would appear directly above or below the cricopharyngeal muscle.(22)A Zenker’s diverticulum can become filled with food or liquid as the patient swallows, which can result in regurgitation or aspiration -If this is observed during the MBSS, refer patient to an otolaryngologist or gastroenterologist for further management -Anterior-posterior  view -When the patient swallows barium trials in the anterior-posterior  view, observe for swallowing symmetry(1) -In normal swallowing, the bolus moves through the oral cavity and is propelled into the pharynx in two relatively equal halves (with one half of the bolus propelled to each side of the pharynx simultaneously) -If the bolus does not pass on one side of the larynx/pyriform sinuses, this might indicate weakness on this particular side -Trial of compensatory strategies -Once dysphagia is identified via the MBSS, it is appropriate for the SLP to guide the patient through different compensatory strategies in order to determine which strategies are most beneficial for the patient’s swallowing
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, and cognition should be evaluated by the SLP prior to bringing the patient to the radiology department for the MBSS -Patients who are unable to maintain adequate attention or arousal are not appropriate for an MBSS(1) -The patient might be able to participate if he or she is able to follow verbal or nonverbal commands and is cooperative and compliant with respect to taking barium or barium-coated  food trials

contraindications precautions: Types of dysphagia: Oral dysphagia, pharyngeal dysphagia, or oropharyngeal dysphagia(10) -A screening of esophageal clearance should be included in every MBSS.(6)If the SLP observes impaired esophageal clearance or suspects an esophageal dysphagia, referral to gastroenterology is appropriate for further management(6)
Severity of dysphagia: Mild, moderate, severe, profound
-Mild: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 23 seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are spontaneously cleared; patient coughs appropriately to pharyngeal residue(10)
-Moderate: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 35seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are cleared given a cue; patient coughs to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue given a cue(10)

-Severe: delay of pharyngeal swallow for 510  seconds; oral and pharyngeal residues are not able to be cleared; patient does not cough appropriately to laryngeal penetration or pharyngeal residue; also may have difficulty managing his or her own secretions(10) -Profound: term usually reserved for patients who present with no apparent swallow response, as well as minimal ability to protect the airway

Patients do not always fit into these categories of dysphagia severity; it is also appropriate for the SLP to classify a patient’s dysphagia with the labels minimal, mild-moderate, and moderate-severe(10)

The recommendations for oral feeding are generally based on the severity of dysphagia and overall risk of aspiration(10) -Normal swallow: If the patient presents with what appears to be normal swallowing function, the patient is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid(10) -Minimal impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be minimally impaired swallowing function, the patient is safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the independent use of one or more compensatory strategies(10) -Mild impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be mildly impaired swallowing function, the patient is usually safe for all consistencies of food and liquid with the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 10% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(10) -Mild-moderate  impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be mild-moderate  impairment of swallowing function, the patient will require some modification of his or her diet and will require the use of one or more compensatory strategies; this type of patient generally requires cueing up to 25% of the time to appropriately incorporate compensatory strategies(10) -Moderate impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be moderately impaired swallowing function, the patient will require modification of his or her diet, as well as direct supervision during meals; patient will require frequent cues to use one or more compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient may require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(10) -Moderate-severe  impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be moderate-severe  impairment of swallowing function, the patient will require significant modification of his or her diet, as well as 1:1 assistance during meals with constant cues to use compensatory strategies during meals; this type of patient will require nonoral nutritional or hydrational support(10) -Severe impairment: If the patient presents with what appears to be severely impaired swallowing function, the patient should be made NPO (nothing by mouth) with nonoral means of nutritional and hydrational support; any food or liquid trials should be given by the SLP only during therapy sessions(10) -Profound impairment: Patients who present with what appears to be a profound impairment of swallowing will not be appropriate for any food, liquid, or medication by mouth; patient is generally not appropriate for therapeutic trials of
food or liquid with SLP; the patient’s oral cavity should be aggressively cleaned and suctioned by nursing every 23 hours to prevent infection
For detailed information on specific therapeutic interventions for dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Patients with the diagnosis of dysphagia might be at risk for aspiration. Swallowing precautions/feeding guidelines should be posted at bedside and caregivers, family members, and nursing staff should be educated regarding patient’s risk of aspiration

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols ›Diagnosis/results of assessment:  Following an MBSS, the SLP will state whether or not the patient presents with dysphagia.(13) Generally, the SLP will make a statement regarding the type and severity of dysphagia.(10)It is important that the SLP who completes the MBSS provide a detailed description of the underlying physiological impairments (e.g., reduced base of tongue retraction, reduced upper esophageal sphincter opening) so that the treating SLP can develop an appropriate and effective treatment plan.(30,31)If the patient does present with dysphagia, the SLP will provide recommendations regarding oral feedings as well as expected treatment plan(10,13)
Treatment plan:  Treatment plan can include recommendations for direct, indirect, compensatory, or facilitative dysphagia therapy(13)
contraindications precautions.general: Following an MBSS, the SLP will state whether or not the patient presents with

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the successful treatment of dysphagia(15) Referral to gastroenterologist for patients in whom esophageal dysphagia or dysmotility is suspected(14,15) Referral to neurologist for patients with dysphagia who do not have a known underlying diagnosis(15) Referral to pulmonologist for patients who appear to have poor respiratory status and/or function(15) Referral to otolaryngologist for patients who present with apparent vocal fold dysfunction(14)  Referral to nutrition services/dietician for patients with poor oral intake or those at risk for malnutrition(13,15,23) Referral to physical and/or occupational therapy for patients with poor posture, difficulty sitting up in the bed or chair, or difficulty feeding themselves(15) See Description , Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A .

patient education: Information about dysphagia is available for patients and family members on the ASHA website at http://www.asha.org/ public/speech/swallowing/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
